instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2939: What is 820-2939? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello, 
I have a board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2939</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, green light, no fan spin

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> 0v

????<SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V


Already replaced <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>
Always <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: PPBUS is 12.4? That is too low possibly crap under the SMC. Double check that measurement.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?
Be sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 1 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0v is missing ( when I have to get this signal ?)
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.22v

I don't have the original Cable but I have a 85w cable with the power supply, this one that i use for repair.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 12.22 is too low. Start by reflowing the SMC. If it doesn?t go to 12.6, then either bad ISL or bad SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replaced ISL and reballed SMC, same problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Probably need to change SMC.
Check first diode mode and voltage on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: SCL/SDA 3.4v, diode mode was 0.23 on both line, I replaced the ISL now it is 0.512

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Voltage on PPBUS now? If still 12.2, replace SMC MUST come from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes still 12.22v, okay I will buy a donor board
